that we're introducing support for

this in the end display settings there's
now an upscaling method option and so by
default this will use TSR but uh you'll
be able to switch between all the
different modes explicitly right so
instead of TSR you can also now switch
to DLSS if you have that plugin enabled
uh and then this will then be based on
like the different quality settings that
DLSS offers uh so in practice what this

default what you what you're what you've

we'll be able to share some clips like

sometimes DLSS may work better,
sometimes TSR may work better. Uh and
really like the operator control is key,

this feature, we just wanted to make
sure that operators had the flexibility

to both the outer viewports and the

Um, another thing to be aware of for
operators is that, you know, they're
people are generally pretty accustomed
to manipulating screen percentage to to

that's still going to be the case with
DLSS, but they now use these names,
right? So, the named uh quality settings
for DLSS, they equate to uh, you know,
screen percentage equivalents in uh,
Unreal, right? So, the ultra performance
option is is 33%. The performance option
of DLSS is 50%. Um there's a balanced
option at 58, a quality option at 66, uh
and then the full 100% is called DAA. So
like for any of the operators that are
accustomed to punching in these numbers,
when you see those names uh in in uh in
the DLSS menu, that's what they equate
to. And so like you you will still
technically be able to change the screen
per second to something else, but it
kind of just rounds up to basically like
whatever you're closest to. And so
that's why in the settings like they'll
just be toggles. Like you won't have to
punch the numbers in anymore. When
you're using DLSS, you're going to put
yourself in the mental model of the
settings that they offer.
